data.title: UBS GAAP EPS of $0.23, revenue of $11.64B; reaffirms long-term financial targets
data.description:
• UBS press release (NYSE:UBS): Q4 GAAP EPS of $0.23.
  • Revenue of $11.64B (+7.2% Y/Y).
  • 4Q24 PBT of $1.0B and underlying1 PBT of $1.8B, up 198% Y/Y, net profit of $0.8B, RoCET1 4.2% and underlying RoCET1 of 7.2%.
  • UBS proposes $0.90 dividend per share and continuation of share repurchases; continuing to invest for long-term growth.
  • UBS Group finished the year with 14.3% CET1 capital ratio and 4.7% CET1 leverage ratio.
  • Outook: Attractive capital returns to continue in 2025, accruing for around 10% growth in dividend per share; plan to repurchase USD 1bn of shares in the first half of 2025 and aim to repurchase up to an additional USD 2bn in the second half. Share repurchase levels will be consistent with maintaining our target CET1 ratio of ~14%.
  • Confirming financial targets and ambitions for 2026 exit rate and 2028, targeting underlying RoCET1 of ~15% and underlying cost/income ratio of <70% as of 2026 exit rate; well positioned to deliver long-term growth and higher returns with ~18% reported RoCET1 in 2028.
  • On track to deliver USD ~13bn gross cost reductions by end-2026 with cumulative integration expenses of USD ~14bn; USD ~2.5bn of gross cost saves expected in 2025.
  • "In the first quarter, we expect a low-to-mid single digit percentage sequential decline in net interest income in Global Wealth Management and around a 10% sequential decline in Personal & Corporate Banking’s NII, measured in Swiss francs."

data.title: Asia markets rebound on Trump tariff delays; eyes on Trump and Xi talks amid tariff dispute
data.description:
Asia-Pacific markets rise on Tuesday as concerns about a potential trade war eased after U.S. President Donald Trump delayed tariffs on Canada and Mexico for a month.

Late on Monday, President Donald Trump agreed to “immediately pause” tariffs on Mexico and Canada for a month following successful negotiations with their respective leaders. Markets are also growing more optimistic that the U.S. and China could reach a deal to avert the 10% tariffs on Chinese imports set to take effect later today.

Japan (NKY:IND) rose 0.76% to around 39,150, while the broader Topix Index rose 1.4% to 2,757 on Tuesday, recouping some of the losses from the previous session. The Japanese yen fell past 155 per dollar on Tuesday, struggling to regain momentum as the suspension of U.S. tariffs on Mexico and Canada reduced demand for the safe-haven currency.

Investors are also looking ahead to Wednesday’s release of Japan’s latest wage figures, which could influence the outlook for Bank of Japan monetary policy.

China (SHCOMP) flat, the offshore yuan held steady around 7.30 per dollar, after recovering from a record low overnight, driven by optimism about a possible trade deal to avoid 10% tariffs on Chinese goods.

US President Donald Trump is reportedly set to speak with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, as soon as this week, as the two largest economies are working toward a deal to avoid broader trade tensions, according to the White House.

Investors are now eyeing upcoming additional PMI data and inflation figures next week.

Hong Kong (HSI) rose 1.71% to a near 8-week high of 20,674 during the Tuesday morning session, following a muted close the prior day.

India (SENSEX) rose 0.50% to 77,684, while the Nifty 50 was above 23,500 in Tuesday morning trade, mainly supported by gains in metals, oil & gas, banking, and tech sectors.

The RBI interest rate decision, which will be announced later this week, also lifted sentiment, with the market expecting the central bank to cut rates by 25 bps amid a slowdown in GDP growth.

Australia (AS51) fell 0.06% to rise above 8,430 on Tuesday, recovering some losses from the previous session. The Australian dollar stabilized above $0.62 on Tuesday, recovering from multi-year lows reached in the previous session.

In Australia, investors are awaiting December trade figures, due on Thursday, to assess the strength of the country’s export-driven economy.

In the U.S., on Monday, all three major indexes ended in red, markets pared some losses after Trump said the US would delay tariffs on Mexican imports by a month following a call with Mexico’s President.

U.S. stock futures climbed on Tuesday after President Donald Trump postponed planned tariffs on goods from Canada, echoing the reprieve given to Mexico just hours earlier: Dow -0.30%; S&P 500 -0.36%; Nasdaq -0.51%.

Investors are now focused on upcoming earnings reports from major companies like Alphabet, AMD, and PayPal on Tuesday. Additionally, Friday’s nonfarm payrolls report is expected to provide more insight into the state of the labor market.

Currencies: (JPY:USD), (CNY:USD), (AUD:USD), (INR:USD), (HKD:USD), (NZD:USD).

More on Asia:

  • U.S. will delay Canada tariffs as countries work on beefing up border security

  • U.S. to delay tariffs on Mexico after Mexico agrees to deploy 10,000 border troops

  • Australia's retail sales fall by 0.1% M/M in December, marks first decline in nine months

  • China’s manufacturing PMI drops to 50.1 in January, missing expectations

  • U.S. futures sharply lower after Trump hits Canada, Mexico and China with tariffs

  • Australia's Q4 producer inflation rise 0.8% Q/Q, misses estimates

data.title: Pennant buys senior living communities in Idaho and Texas
data.description:
The Pennant Group (NASDAQ:PNTG), the parent company of the Pennant group of affiliated home health, hospice, home care and senior living companies, said that effective February 1, 2025, it has acquired three premier senior living facilities in Idaho and Texas.

The acquisition in Idaho is subject to a triple net lease with the option to purchase, and the two Texas facilities are subject to a long-term, triple net lease.

“The acquisitions in Idaho and Texas represent another step forward for Pennant as we continue to expand our operations in key markets across the country,” said Brent Guerisoli, CEO.

data.title: Salesforce to cut 1,000 jobs while hiring for AI roles - report
Tuesday's Economic Calendar
data.description:
Auto Sales

10:00 AM Factory Orders

Factory Orders measures the change in the total value of new purchase orders placed with manufacturers. December new orders are expected to fall 0.6% after a drop of 0.4% in November.

10:00 AM Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey

A survey done by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics collects data from employers about their businesses' employment, job openings, recruitment, hires and separations. December job openings are expected to be 8.00 million from 8.098 million in November.

11:00 AM Fed's Bostic Speech

Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Raphael Bostic speaks on housing in a moderated conversation before a National Housing Crisis Task Force Meeting.

2:00 PM Fed's Daly: "The Economy 2025: the Impacts of Tariffs, Tax Cuts and Trump"

San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President Mary Daly participates in hybrid discussion, "The Economy 2025: the Impacts of Tariffs, Tax Cuts and Trump" before the Commonwealth Club World Affairs of California.

7:30 PM Fed's Jefferson: Economic Outlook

Federal Reserve Vice Chair Philip Jefferson speaks on the U.S. economic outlook and monetary policy before the Lafayette College Economics Department Special Lecture.

data.title: BriaCell Therapeutics slumps 20%, prices $3M stock offering
data.description:
• Clinical-stage biotechnology company BriaCell Therapeutics (NASDAQ:BCTX) priced a public offering of 762,500 common shares at a public offering price of $4.00 per share.
  • Total gross proceeds are expected to be $3.05M.
  • The offering is expected to close on February 5, 2025.
  • The company intends to use the net proceeds for working capital requirements, general corporate purposes, and the advancement of business objectives.
  • The stock price slumped 20% on Monday during after market hours of trading.

data.title: Kforce targets $1.7B annual revenue with new offshore facility in India
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Kforce Inc. (NYSE:KFRC) Q4 2024

Management View

  • Joe Liberatore, President and CEO, highlighted the company's stability in the technology services market and reaffirmed its focus on long-term growth strategies. He emphasized the operational readiness of Kforce’s new India Development Center, which officially opened in January 2025. This offshore facility is expected to expand the company's capabilities for delivering blended onshore, nearshore, and offshore solutions, addressing evolving client demands.

  • Liberatore reiterated the company’s financial objectives of reaching $1.7 billion in annual revenue, with a longer-term target of at least 10% operating margins at $2.1 billion in annual revenue. He acknowledged that clients remain cautious, delaying technology projects due to macroeconomic uncertainties, but expressed optimism that confidence and project investments could improve later in 2025.

  • CFO Jeff Hackman noted, "Earnings per share of $0.60 were at the midpoint of our guidance," and explained that higher-than-expected healthcare costs had impacted margins. He also mentioned that operating cash flows were $22 million for the quarter, while $65 million in capital was returned to shareholders for the full year through dividends and share repurchases.

Outlook

  • Kforce projects Q1 2025 revenue to range between $330 million and $338 million, with earnings per share expected to fall between $0.44 and $0.52. This guidance reflects typical seasonal tax resets and holiday impacts but assumes a stable demand environment.

  • Management remains optimistic about the long-term potential of AI and other innovative technologies to drive demand for technology services. Conversations with clients suggest a backlog of strategically important technology projects, which could be activated once economic confidence improves.

  • The India Development Center is expected to contribute to revenue growth in 2025, although the ramp-up will be gradual and directly driven by client needs for offshore delivery capabilities.

Financial Results

  • Fourth-quarter revenue totaled $343.8 million, exceeding the midpoint of guidance and reflecting a 0.4% sequential growth on a billing day basis. The company’s technology business grew 0.6% sequentially, while year-over-year revenue declined by 5.2% per billing day.

  • Flex margins in the technology business declined 80 basis points sequentially, primarily due to higher healthcare costs and holiday seasonality. However, bill-pay spreads remained stable year-over-year, signaling resilience in pricing.

  • Full-year 2024 revenue came in at $1.41 billion, a 9% decrease year-over-year, with earnings per share at $2.68. Operating cash flows for the year amounted to $87 million, with significant capital returned to shareholders.

Q&A

  • Mark Marcon, Baird: Questioned what Kforce's clients need to see to initiate delayed technology projects. Joe Liberatore responded, "Clients are looking for predictability and stability," and noted increased client meetings and job orders as early indicators of improving sentiment.

  • Trevor Romeo, William Blair: Inquired about historical recovery cycles and how client confidence translates into spending. Liberatore explained that project work typically resumes before full-time hiring, adding, "We are well-positioned to benefit from these cycles with our diversified client base."

  • Kartik Mehta, Northcoast Research: Asked about capacity utilization and flexibility in scaling operations. Dave Kelly emphasized that the company has ample capacity to absorb demand increases without significant new investments, highlighting the scalability of its India Development Center.

  • Tobey Sommer, Truist Securities: Asked about the drivers behind the expected 100 basis points improvement in operating margins when revenue returns to $1.7 billion. CFO Jeff Hackman cited cost efficiencies from the India facility, integrated solutions offerings, and back-office transformations as significant contributors.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, probing for clarity on demand trends and the potential timing of project backlogs materializing. Questions reflected curiosity about the company's ability to unlock opportunities in a challenging macro environment.

  • Management’s tone was confident and forward-looking, particularly regarding its strategic initiatives like the India Development Center and AI-focused solutions. However, responses to near-term demand visibility remained measured, emphasizing stability rather than immediate growth.

  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone reflected slightly higher optimism, supported by modest improvements in client activity and early indicators of confidence.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Revenue stability persisted, with Q4 revenue slightly exceeding guidance, compared to a modest sequential decline in Q3. Earnings per share remained within the guided range, though slightly lower than Q3 EPS of $0.75.

  • Strategic focus shifted further to long-term growth initiatives, with the operational launch of the India Development Center adding a significant new capability.

  • Analysts maintained consistent concerns about macroeconomic uncertainties but showed increased interest in AI-driven opportunities and offshore delivery capabilities.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management flagged the uncertain macroeconomic environment, including client hesitancy to initiate projects due to inflationary pressures and geopolitical concerns.

  • Healthcare cost volatility significantly impacted Q4 margins, emphasizing a potential area of ongoing financial risk.

  • Analysts raised questions about the scalability and profitability of the new India facility, reflecting broader concerns about execution risks for offshore expansion.

Final Takeaway

Kforce's Q4 2024 earnings call highlighted the company’s focus on stability and strategic growth amid macroeconomic uncertainties. The operational launch of the India Development Center marks a key milestone, positioning the company to capture offshore and blended project opportunities. While the near-term demand environment remains subdued, Kforce’s investments in AI-related services and long-term margin improvements signal confidence in its ability to achieve $1.7 billion in annual revenue and double-digit operating margins in future years.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Woodward narrows 2025 EPS guidance to $5.85-$6.25 amid aerospace growth and industrial challenges
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Woodward, Inc. (NASDAQ:WWD) Q1 2025

Management View

  • CEO Chip Blankenship highlighted robust demand in core industrial and aerospace segments despite a slight year-over-year decline in overall results. He emphasized operational improvements, lean transformation progress, and automation investments as drivers for long-term growth. A key strategic move was the acquisition of Safran Electronics & Defense's electromechanical actuation business, which bolsters technology offerings and expands content on the Airbus A350.
  • Blankenship noted adjustments in response to Boeing's paused 737 MAX production, including balancing labor across other product lines and preparing for higher demand signals. Defense markets were identified as a growth driver, supported by geopolitical factors and increased production activity.
  • CFO Bill Lacey reported first-quarter net sales of $773 million, with adjusted EPS at $1.35. He attributed Aerospace segment growth to strong aftermarket and defense OEM performance, while the Industrial segment faced a 15% decline, primarily due to reduced China on-highway sales.
  • Lacey reaffirmed the company's 2025 guidance with adjusted EPS narrowed to $5.85-$6.25, reflecting a favorable tax rate.

Outlook

  • Management reaffirmed 2025 guidance, projecting adjusted EPS between $5.85 and $6.25 and total sales between $3.3 billion and $3.5 billion. Aerospace sales are expected to grow 6%-13%, with segment earnings at 20%-21%. Core industrial sales are forecasted to grow 3%-7%, with margins of 14%-15%.
  • Blankenship emphasized flexibility to meet anticipated growth in aerospace OEM demand and robust defense production. Commercial aftermarket activity is projected to remain healthy due to high utilization rates of legacy aircraft and engines.
  • Lacey noted that core industrial margins are expected to stabilize between 14%-15% for the year, supported by operational improvements and pricing actions.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EPS for Q1 2025 was $1.35 vs. analysts' estimate of $1.18. Net sales of $773 million were in line with estimates of $772.3 million. Aerospace segment sales increased 7%, driven by 19% growth in commercial aftermarket and 21% in defense OEM. Defense aftermarket sales also rose 8%.
  • Industrial segment sales declined 15% due to continued weakness in China on-highway sales, offset by 7% growth in core industrial markets. Core margins reached approximately 15%.
  • Free cash flow was $1 million, reflecting lower earnings and reduced capital expenditures.

Q&A

  • Scott Mikus, Melius Research, inquired about the aerospace segment's guidance range and pecking order of growth. Blankenship stated that defense OEM remains the largest driver, while commercial aftermarket and OEM growth will depend on supply chain conditions and Boeing's recovery pace.
  • Sheila Kahyaoglu, Jefferies, asked about shop visit revenue and aftermarket cadence. Blankenship clarified that revenue is primarily tied to engine hours rather than event-driven shop visits, with LEAP and GTF engine inputs growing steadily.
  • Matthew Akers, Wells Fargo, sought details on the Safran acquisition. Blankenship highlighted its strategic importance in enhancing electromechanical flight control capabilities and increasing content on single-aisle aircraft.
  • Noah Poponak, Goldman Sachs, questioned LEAP engine aftermarket contributions. Management noted strong growth, though the segment remains small relative to legacy engines, with critical mass expected around 2028.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analyst tone was neutral to slightly positive, with focused questions on aerospace growth, industrial margins, and the Safran acquisition. Skepticism was observed regarding the China on-highway outlook.
  • Management maintained a confident tone during prepared remarks, emphasizing strategic progress and market opportunities. In the Q&A, responses were measured but optimistic, with a focus on addressing operational challenges.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, there was consistency in management's confidence, though the tone was slightly more cautious regarding industrial performance.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management narrowed adjusted EPS guidance for 2025, reflecting improved tax assumptions. Strategic focus shifted to integrating the Safran acquisition and addressing supply chain challenges in aerospace.
  • Analysts maintained their focus on aerospace growth and defense contributions, while concerns about industrial margins and China on-highway sales persisted.
  • Operational improvements and lean initiatives were emphasized in both quarters, with Q1 showcasing tangible progress in automation and labor adaptations.
  • Tone remained consistent, though the current quarter reflected a heightened focus on addressing industrial headwinds and capitalizing on aerospace opportunities.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited ongoing supplier challenges and labor constraints as potential risks to meeting demand signals, particularly in aerospace.
  • Analysts expressed concerns over China on-highway sales volatility and the impact of supply chain disruptions on growth projections.
  • Mitigation efforts include forward-deployed problem-solving with suppliers and investments in flexible manufacturing equipment to alleviate bottlenecks.

Final Takeaway

Woodward's Q1 2025 performance reflected resilience in aerospace and core industrial segments amid headwinds in China on-highway sales. Strategic moves, including the Safran acquisition and automation advancements, position the company for long-term growth. The reaffirmed guidance underscores confidence in demand across aerospace and defense markets, with operational improvements supporting margin stability. However, supply chain challenges and industrial market volatility remain key risks to monitor.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Clorox forecasts 25-50 bps EBIT margin expansion starting FY2026 with ERP-driven growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: The Clorox Company (NYSE:CLX) Q2 2025

Management View

  • CEO Linda Rendle announced a CFO transition, with Kevin Jacobsen retiring after nearly 30 years and Luc Bellet stepping in as CFO on April 1, 2025. Rendle highlighted Bellet’s extensive experience and confidence in continuing the company’s strategic transformation.
  • Rendle shared enthusiasm for assuming full control of the Glad business in 2026, following the mutual decision with Procter & Gamble not to renew their joint agreement. She emphasized that Clorox retains key intellectual property and is well-positioned to drive innovation and growth for the brand.
  • CFO Kevin Jacobsen outlined the company’s strong confidence in achieving 44% gross margins this fiscal year and outlined plans to expand EBIT margins by 25 to 50 basis points annually from FY2026 onwards, supported by productivity initiatives, ERP implementation, and margin transformation strategies.

Outlook

  • Management reaffirmed their fiscal year guidance for organic sales growth of 4% to 7%, with noticeable variability between quarters due to ERP-related timing. For Q3, organic sales are expected to grow in the low single digits, while Q4 is projected to rise mid-to-high single digits, driven by ERP-related inventory adjustments.
  • Jacobsen emphasized confidence in achieving EBIT margin expansion starting FY2026, supported by continued productivity improvements, net revenue management, and enhanced cost-saving tools.
  • Management anticipates maintaining competitive promotional levels in categories like Litter and Glad, while continuing to invest in innovation and advertising.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EPS for Q2 reached $1.40, aligning with analysts’ estimates. Revenue was reported at $1.63B, also in line with expectations.
  • Gross margins achieved 44%, reflecting strong cost savings and improved product mix, despite headwinds from competitive promotions in the Glad and Litter categories.
  • Organic sales declined 9.5%, driven by planned reductions in certain categories, yet share gains were recorded in seven of eight categories, with significant improvement in Bleach and Fresh Step.
  • Management noted that ERP-related shipment benefits, expected in Q4, will temporarily boost sales and inventory levels before normalizing in FY2026.

Q&A

  • Dara Mohsenian, Morgan Stanley: Asked about long-term gross margin expansion beyond FY2025 and drivers. CFO Jacobsen stated, "We feel very confident in our ability to rebuild gross margins to 44% this year and expand EBIT margins by 25 to 50 basis points annually starting FY2026."
  • Peter Grom, UBS: Queried about variability in sales guidance and Q4 drivers. Jacobsen explained that Q4 organic sales growth will benefit temporarily from ERP-related inventory adjustments, expected to add 1 to 2 points to growth.
  • Filippo Falorni, Citi: Inquired about promotional activity in Litter and Glad. Rendle noted elevated competition in Glad but affirmed that innovation and advertising are driving share gains in both categories.
  • Bonnie Herzog, Goldman Sachs: Asked about ERP risks and mitigation strategies. Bellet explained detailed inventory build-up plans to prevent disruptions during the U.S. ERP transition.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts showed cautious optimism, raising concerns about ERP-related noise in financials and sustained promotional pressures in certain categories. Questions were probing yet supportive.
  • Management maintained a confident tone, emphasizing transformative actions and strategic investments. Key phrases such as "we feel very confident" and "we are well-equipped" demonstrated a proactive and optimistic outlook.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remained consistent, with continued focus on operational stability and margin expansion.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language has remained consistent, emphasizing EBIT margin expansion and productivity improvements. However, new details were shared regarding ERP’s short-term impacts on sales and inventory.
  • Analysts continued to focus on category dynamics and the competitive landscape, particularly in Litter and Glad, mirroring concerns raised in the previous quarter.
  • Gross margin performance remained a central theme, with Q2 reflecting progress towards the target of 44% for FY2025.
  • Management tone maintained a forward-looking and confident stance, mirroring the sentiment from Q1.

Risks and Concerns

  • Elevated promotional activity in categories like Glad and Litter was highlighted as a competitive pressure. Management noted that increased trade spending has been factored into the outlook.
  • ERP transition in the U.S. introduces temporary sales and inventory fluctuations, though management emphasized detailed planning to mitigate risks.
  • Continued FX headwinds and rising trade competition in international markets remain challenges.

Final Takeaway

Clorox’s Q2 2025 earnings call underscored the company’s focus on operational stability, with anticipated gross margin recovery to 44% and EBIT margin expansion of 25 to 50 basis points annually starting in FY2026. The ERP transition and full control of the Glad business were key strategic highlights, along with ongoing investments in innovation and promotional activities to sustain market share growth. While competitive pressures and ERP-related noise may weigh on near-term results, management expressed confidence in achieving long-term growth and profitability targets.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Senate confirms Wright as Trump's energy secretary, while Burgum gets down to business
data.description:
The U.S. Senate on Monday confirmed Chris Wright, CEO of Liberty Energy (NYSE:LBRT) since 2011, as President Trump's new Secretary of Energy, with seven Democrats and one Independent who caucuses with Democrats crossing the aisle in a 59-38 vote.

In his confirmation hearing, Wright said his first priority is to expand domestic energy production, including liquefied natural gas and nuclear energy; he also was a board member of small modular reactor startup Oklo (OKLO).

Wright also said in his hearing that deadly wildfires that recently devastated the Los Angeles area are "heartbreaking," but he defended his comments on social media in 2023 that "hype over wildfires is just hype to justify" policies to curb climate change.

He is expected to play a prominent role in a new national energy dominance council to be led by newly confirmed Secretary of the Interior and former North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum.

On his first day in his new position, Burgum issued a flurry of orders directing agency staff to identify emergency and legal authorities to speed project development and permitting, and to eliminate burdensome regulations in part by reviewing appropriations under the Biden-era Inflation Reduction Act and Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act laws.

The moves signal a major shift at the Interior Department after the Biden administration had sought to slow new fossil fuel development on public lands and waters while encouraging renewable energy in an effort to combat climate change.

ETFs: (XLE), (XOP), (AMLP), (VDE), (OIH), (IXC)
